reviewText: Game-breaking bugs only present in Rockin' Android's Steam version. Has been acknowledged as an issue since August '15 or earlier, albeit only in the comments thread of an old update. No fix or ETA for a fix as of January '16. No public statement. Getting ahold of customer service is like pulling teeth. I can't recommend anyone purchases this or any other Rockin' Android game until they change the way they support their products and treat their customers.

reviewText:
Update (16th August 2015):
I'm changing this to Not Recommended for reasons explained below.

It seems that an update breaks the game, allowing you to shoot absurdly more bullets than you normally could. As a result, most bosses can be shot down in about half the time you're supposed to take (or even less depending on your shot type). Also for some reason, pressing certain buttons makes the character shoot in a specific direction instead of my desired direction. I'm not sure if it's due to the strafing settings (I chose the third one) or it's because I play the game with the gamepad/controller. Either way, this NEEDS to be fixed before I can recommend this game again.

Until these issues are patched out or someone can recommend a solution, I do not recommend getting this game. Sorry.

================
ORIGINAL REVIEW (Recommended at the time):

Diadra Empty is an obscure and awesome free-roaming bullet hell shooter unlike most other games in the recent years.

The game allows you to use up to two different weapons to shoot stuff, in which you will even unlock more as you keep playing. You are also allowed to dash to be temporarily invincible to cover against most bullet waves and can be used as an attack. Should you get hit by an enemy or a bullet, there's a Defense mechanic where shields you from losing a life once until it recharges back to full. The game also has an upgrade system where you use up gathered coins to power up certain things such as your weapon shots or movement speed. You will definitely be playing this game more times not only to unlock more weapons to choose from but also to unlock other game modes (haven't tried them yet as of this review) and as well as more useful tips in the main menu. There are a few bugs here and there (Results Screen displaying incorrectly is one of them) but none of them affects the gameplay so far. Also, you should NEVER hit the Escape button if you play this game with your keyboard.

The soundtrack is also pretty good and it blends in with the game's atmosphere.

There's not much else I can say here and it's extremely hard for me to express the game in words. I'd recommend watching the trailer in the store page to see it for yourself (There are a few gameplay videos of this game on YouTube, but there's also a longplay of it by Rockin' Android if you're interested.). I don't know if there is a demo present, but you're free to explore around to find it. This game was on Steam Greenlight but there was no mentioning of the game's release for over a year. Thus, the game became obscured within the depths of Steam.

This review may be updated once I've play a couple more times in this game and/or something else happens here.

reviewText:
A good bullet hell game does not need a long story
.
.
.
.
.
.
Maybe a long review? I don't even.

Game control 6/10
Pausing mechanism is slightly annoying that you have to use S key to pause instead of ESC key. Which this ESC key directly brings you back to your desktop and results in you staring at your desktop for full 10 seconds and asking yourself isn't ESC the pause key?

Game play 8/10
Standard bullet hell game, however, it does introduce an upgrade system allows you to upgrade your character's abilities. Since you can only control one character, the game provides you new weapon every time when you level up 3 full levels until you successfully unlocked every type of options. As for game play itself, screen full of bullets and enemies are expected. However, the game uses turbo movement(makes the character move faster) instead of precise movement(makes the character move slower), results in easier to escape from enemies but harder to fight the bosses since it gets harder to approach bosses while avoiding bullets. Overall the game flows really well as a bullet hell game, however, I do not appreciate the game throws three bosses into my face in a row.

User Interface 5/10
It is user friendly, shows all the controls upon player starting the game. However, a major problem is the game provides you the option to use ESC to exit the game and P key to pause the game. This is not really a problem until players realize using ESC to exit the game will not save the player's status. In order to save the status, player is required to use the Exit option in the menu, rendering ESC key completely useless or downright annoying. Art style is enjoyable.

Background Music 7/10
It fits the genre of bullet hell games, which is similar to Touhou project in my opinion. An audio setting option will be nice though, really.

Overall 7/10 Slightly annoying UI
Otherwise, this game should be a refreshing game if you like bullet hell games or want to try this type of games.

reviewText:
Changing this review to negative, lot of good it will do, due to bugs that are STILL present and not a word from RA on when they'll be fixed. Below is still the positive review.
Might just be me, but I found this to be one of the most beautiful SHMUPs I have ever played. It's hard to precisely express what it is about this game that got me to feel this way, but to make an attempt: its atmosphere, music, and story about Nyalra's desperate struggle to be reunited with her sister against a seemingly endless horde of... things, all build up to a powerful experience that should be experienced by all SHMUP fans looking for something a bit offbeat. This game builds a world that sucked me in and brought me on quite the emotional rollercoaster. Mechanics wise it's also fun. There are a lot of options and weapon types to choose from and there's a lot of replayability to be had.

It's a shame that this game is currently mired with bugs that haven't been addressed yet. Throughout the game I faced the bug that just lets your weapon keep shooting even if you aren't pressing the fire button. I really wish Rockin' Android would fix some of these issues and other issues in other past titles because they have some great games worth playing, but you'll have to deal with issues to play them.

reviewText:
I've adored this game since its original japanese release.
One of my favourite shmups, about a little girl looking for her sister, whilst also shooting a bajillion enemies in the face from the comfort of her cute little dragon buddy.
Art and style is beautiful, as too is the music.
Entirely worth the pittance they are asking for it.

reviewText: Great game, with an absolutely wonderful soundtrack.  If you like bullet hell games, you'll love this! The first couple stages aren't that bad at all, but once you get to stage 5 it gets real, man!  You won't just be dodging bullets, but dragons, birds, sharp metal objects, tiny metal objects, and... beams of light!  I like being able to traverse the skies and find an escape when things get super tough, and that's something you don't always get in games like this.  Bosses are tough, buy as many upgrades as you can, they will save you.  Recommended!  Great challenge at an affordable price!

reviewText:

I would be more than happy to change my review to positive if either a screen resolution option OR a change to fullscreen mode option (or both options) where added to the game.

Beautiful and fun game, nice original graphics and sound.
I didnt encounter (yet) the Steam version bugs that everyone is talking about (however I should say that I didnt play the game for too long yet).

Negative side:
The game completely lacks screen options that allow to play it fullscreen, or change screen resolution.
I use a big, FullHD TV set and have it somewhat far from me;
and playing the game in a  small   window isnt the best way to appreciate the cool graphics it has.

reviewText:
Summary: Hori bullet hell with upgrades
Multiplayer: No
Completion: 3 hrs
Cards: Yes
Cloud: Yes

In a nutshell, Diadra Empty is a horizontal bullet hell style game, with the ability to upgrade your weapons and defenses between rounds. An obvious analogue to this is the Touhou series, except imagine that horizontally. You play in a single, large rectangular field with no terrain obstacles, and the ability to face and move backwards. The field does not wrap around, so it's quite possible to get cornered. Fortunately the game provides you with a turbo" boost that you can use to become temporarily invulnerable
date: and a handful of bombs (called "Storm Savers") to convert enemy bullets on-screen into cash.  Between rounds
recommended: you are given several categories to upgrade your character using coins you gathered throughout your journey. I like that every weapon undergoes a visible upgrade
hoursPlayed: so you feel like you are getting stronger.\n\nThe story is about a girl
voteText: Nyalra who sets out to find her sister whilst riding atop her dragon
votesHelpful: though you wouldn't really get that unless you looked at the store page or manual. The narrative is told through occasional sentences at the start of each stage and the ending sequence. It goes for a somewhat minimal
commentsCount: so I'll just leave it at that.\n\nDiadra is a rather pretty game
column16: if you can stop and appreciate the bazillion bullet patterns on the screen. I haven't experienced any slowdown like I have in some other titles
column17: so that's a good sign. On top of that
column18: Diadra boasts some nice relaxing music
column19: mostly somber piano scores or upbeat electronica. One criticism I have is that the story font is really tiny. The game is always in a 4:3 aspect ratio
column20: which results in side bars on a widescreen monitor. I have to get up close to the screen to read the story text
column21: which is displayed on the screen very briefly. It's hard on the eyes and by the time I realized there was text on the screen
column22: it was usually gone.\n\nThe game offers three difficulty levels. Each must be unlocked in ascending order by completing the previous one. The easiest difficulty is a nice pace. It's not too hard and not exactly a cakewalk either. But after that
column23: the game goes all out and goes nuts with the bullets and enemy health. Surprisingly the difficulty settings set up each stage differently. It's not just a simple damage and health multiplier; more enemies spawn
column25: and more bullets are fired faster. And bosses galore.\n\nI'm not entirely sure what the process is to unlock new weapons and features. I presume it all boils down to "play more"
column26: but I don't know how much more they expect me to play. I would have liked the game to explain the requirements for unlockables.\n\nThere's not a great deal of replay value
column27: other than trying to unlock stuff. I rate Diadra Empty a 7/10. It's short
column29: and hectic. As far as bullet hell games go
column30: this is one of the better ones."

reviewText:
Diadra Empty is a very interesting bullet hell with very innovative mechanics.
There are lots of customizations available through progression from shoot types to evasive maneuver where you can combine them to fit your gameplay style or try something new.

The soundtrack varies from Meh" to "Awesome" while the sound effects are not remarkable at all.

There are several unlockable content to be digged out.

The major problem with this game is that the base resolution is too low so the only available options are:
- Play windowed at 800x600
- Play FULLSCREEN but as mandatory enable 640x480 on windows compatibility mode otherwise the game will not open

"

reviewText:
An overall excellent SHMUP.  Some of my thoughts on the game:

- Not quite bullet-hell in the way most may be used to.  Rather than micro-dodging elaborate patterns, you're avoiding the main avenues of fire while shooting the smaller 'chip' shots out of the sky before they reach you.  You have a Strafe that gives you limited invulnerability to break through large walls of fire/enemies to reach a more favorable position.

- Art direction is lovely, although it's hard to make out exactly what some of the small sprites are, haha.  The visual effects can be a problem in the insanity toward the end of EXTRA, but otherwise it's okay as long as you're paying attention.

- The soundtrack is incredible, and the entire reason I became interested in the game.  In particular, 'Nebula', the theme from the crazy-to-reach-let-alone-clear EXTRA Stage 5, has become one of my favorite tracks in games, period.

- As others have noted, the are unfortunately several bugs in this port, and it's unknown if we'll get any fix.  None are gamebreaking and there's a few workarounds, but don't expect to get a good read on your scores.

- There's a lot of customization in your shots.  3 Turbo styles (Hold, toggle, side shooting), fully mappable buttons, 12 shot types, etc.  Some things are locked at the start, and are unlocked after a certain number of cumulative level ups across all playthroughs.  It's also controller-friendly if you prefer.

- Since it's based on macro instead of micro dodging, movement feels a bit too floaty.  You'll also move some on the screen even if you aren't telling it to.  Something to keep in mind so you don't ram a wave of bullets.  Derpy dragons can't hover it seems.

Overall, I recommend you give this a try.  It's not my favorite SHMUP, but it's not one I'm going to forget.

reviewText: In Diadra Empty, you take the role of Nyalra and her faithful dragon Minimi. You embark on an incredible quest to save your sis-MINIMI? Is Nyalra Dr. Evil? Did she take one look at this dragon and say Breathtaking. I shall call him... Minimi."? What the heck kind of title is Diadra Empty anyway? Is Diadra Nyalra's sister? Why is she Empty? Maybe the developer didn't want to call it "Diadra is Missing" because it sounds too much like Mario is Missing. Besides

recommended: and you know what that means; all of the plot is removed so there's room for more bullets. Unlike other side-view shooters

votesTotal: because monsters will come from every possible direction. It also helps to keep an eye on your defender-esque radar. Not only does this beauty keep track of you and the enemies
votesFunny: but it also accounts for projectiles
commentsCount: which is absurd but also amazing.\n\nAll you really need to do
column16: in order to finish this game

column18: and you'll absorb cash from further away. The right combination of weapons is also very important. When you first play the game
column19: your offensive options are pretty limited. As you progress
column22: and even special config options will unlock. In my opinion

column25: so you'll have an easy time memorizing what spawns in each stage. Even the last boss and its multiple forms of increasing ludicrousness isn't too bad once you know when & where to wing-smash. It's also nice that the weapon-selection and upgrade paths lend unique qualities to every play-through. Eventually the natural level of difficulty will feel too easy. If that's the case

column30: after all the insanity in the True and Extra modes.\n\nThe real flaws in this game are due to the Steam port. Some issues (like hi-scores not showing up) don't make any sense at all. I was able to trigger full-screen by setting it in the options

column36: If anyone thinks that this port is inexcusable
column37: then they're perfectly right. I'm not too happy about it either.\n\nDiadra Empty is a really good shooter. It has cool ideas
